item.title: Bajo el control de las pandillas, Haití se enfrenta también a una crisis de liderazgo
item.description: Haití no ha celebrado elecciones desde 2016, y su último presidente, Jovenel Moïse, fue asesinado en 2021. El país tampoco cuenta con un Parlamento en funciones.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, David C. Adams and André Paultre

media:content.media:credit: Clarens Siffroy/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Vista desde el interior de un vehículo blindado de la policía que muestra coches quemados por pandillas armadas y utilizados como barricada en una calle desierta de Puerto Príncipe, Haití, el mes pasado.

item.title: El Super Bowl inolvidable de Bad Bunny
item.description: En medio de la dura retórica de la Casa Blanca, la superestrella puertorriqueña subirá al escenario el domingo con la promesa de un mensaje de unidad: “El mundo bailará”.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario

media:content.media:credit: Amy Lombard para The New York Times; Erika Santelices/Reuters; Emily Kask para The New York Times;

item.title: Partying With Charli XCX at Sundance After Premiere of ‘The Moment’
item.description: The “Brat” pop star isn’t afraid to lean into her party-girl persona. But moving into film with “The Moment” has given her brand-new perspective.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan and Sinna Nasseri

media:content.media:description: For most of her career, Charli saw herself as “famous but not quite.”

item.title: Olympics Officials Signal Sanctions on Russia in Sports May End
item.description: In Milan this week, Olympics officials signaled a willingness to ease years of restrictions imposed on the country over its state-backed doping program and invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Tariq Panja

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Athletes competing for the Russian Olympic Committee in the men’s ice hockey gold medal match at the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing. The team won a silver medal.

item.title: Corrections: Feb. 7, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 7, 2026.

item.title: Quote of the Day: At 41, Vonn Is Going for Gold, on One Good Knee
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 7, 2025.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Why on Earth Won’t This City Stop Shaking?
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 6, 2025.

item.title: Philippe Morillon, General Who Made Fateful Protection Promise, Dies at 90
item.description: “I will never abandon you,” he told residents of Srebrenica amid sectarian armed conflict in Bosnia. The town later suffered the worst massacre in Europe since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia

media:content.media:credit: Peter Northall/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Gen. Philippe Morillon in 1993, as commander of U.N. forces in what was then Bosnia-Herzegovina.

item.title: Use for a Yew
item.description: Mark Diehl dishes out a spicy themeless puzzle.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:credit: Steve Eason/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Stick a feather in your cap for solving this colorful challenge.

item.title: Judge Extends Block on Trump Officials Slashing Funds to Democratic States
item.description: The decision kept at bay a freeze of nearly $10 billion in child care and other social service funds destined for Minnesota and four other Democratic-led states.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim and Zach Montague

media:content.media:credit: Elias Williams for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A preschool program in Manhattan. The Trump administration had sought to choke off funds for child care programs in New York and four other states.

item.title: Hegseth Says Defense Department Will Cut Ties With Harvard
item.description: Mr. Hegseth’s order appeared to target his alma mater, Harvard’s Kennedy School for public policy.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron

media:content.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Harvard Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.

item.title: In a Close Election, Voters Send a Sharp Anti-Trump Message
item.description: The Democratic primary to replace Gov. Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey in Congress is still too close to call. Much of the advertising focused on opposition to the president and his immigration policies.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully

media:content.media:credit: Brian Fraser for The New York Times; Rachel Wisniewski for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Tom Malinowski, left, and Analilia Mejia are in a tight Democratic primary race to fill Gov. Mikie Sherrill’s seat in Congress.

item.title: Super Bowl Visitors Find San Francisco Better Than Its Apocalyptic Image
item.description: Problems with homelessness and open-air drug use have been widely broadcast, but many visitors this week said they found the city surprisingly pleasant.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan and Kellen Browning

media:content.media:credit: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The Ferry Building is a popular spot for visitors walking along San Francisco Bay on the Embarcadero.

item.title: How Is Security Different at These Olympic Games?
item.description: Our sports correspondent Tariq Panja talks with Katrin Bennhold about the security at the Olympics in Italy, including the presence of Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents, who the U.S. says are there only in an advisory role.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja, Katrin Bennhold, Leila Medina and Laura Salaberry

item.title: Psychiatrist Says Kennedy Was ‘Not Accurate’ in Discussing His Keto Studies
item.description: Dr. Christopher M. Palmer said in an interview that the keto diet, while promising, did not “cure” schizophrenia as the health secretary had claimed.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Ellen Barry

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: On Wednesday, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said that “we now know that the things that you eat are driving mental illness in this country,” and that a doctor at Harvard had “cured schizophrenia using keto diets.”

item.title: Haití, campeón indiscutible en ‘looks’ olímpicos
item.description: Los atletas de la nación caribeña querían rendir homenaje a la herencia de su país. El resultado es una serie de atuendos imposibles de ignorar.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman

media:content.media:credit: Gregorio Borgia/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Stella Jean, en el centro, diseñadora haitiano-italiana afincada en Milán, diseñó los uniformes de la delegación de Haití.

item.title: Colorado Funeral Home Director Is Sentenced to 40 Years in Corpse Abuse Case
item.description: “I deserve every word you have said and every day that I will sit in prison,” Jon Hallford said in court on Friday. Investigators found nearly 200 decomposing bodies stored improperly.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Rylee Kirk
item.category: Return to Nature Funeral Home (HallfordHomes LLC)

media:content.media:credit: Parker Seibold/The Gazette, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Local authorities prepare to set up tents outside the Return to Nature Funeral Home where more than 100 bodies were discovered to have been improperly stored, in Penrose, Colo., in 2023.

item.title: Trump Opens Marine National Monument in Atlantic to Commercial Fishing
item.description: Off the coast of Cape Cod, the Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monument is a unique stretch of ocean that had been protected for a decade.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.category: Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monument
Pacific Remote Islands Marine National Monument

media:content.media:credit: NOAA, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A rare sei whale visiting the waters off New England in 2024.

item.title: ‘Melania’ and the Real Housewives of Washington
item.description: The documentary highlights a few notable predecessors in the role, burnishing Mrs. Trump’s image by extension. But one apt comparison is pointedly left out.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: Bad Bunny Explains His ‘Purpose’ in Life
item.description: Bad Bunny sat down with Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, the hosts of Popcast, prior to releasing his Grammy-winning magnum opus, “Debí Tirar Más Fotos,” to discuss how working with young Puerto Rican musicians in his home country ranks among his life’s greatest achievements.

item.title: Republican Chairman of Homeland Security Spending Panel to Exit Congress
item.description: Representative Mark Amodei of Nevada added his name to the growing list of Republicans planning to give up their seats as their party faces losses that could cost them the House.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Representative Mark Amodei, Republican of Nevada, has demonstrated a willingness to criticize the Trump administration’s immigration operations.

item.title: F.B.I. Investigates Links to Biological Labs in Las Vegas and California
item.description: The Las Vegas lab had vials of a “reddish liquid,” the police said. The California lab, uncovered in 2023, had materials “possibly associated with infectious diseases,” officials said.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin

item.title: A First Look Below Antarctica’s Most Menacing Glacier
item.description: Scientists on the Thwaites Glacier attempted to install equipment beneath the ice to better understand how it is melting. Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong walks us through their landmark experiment and the bittersweet outcome.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, Jon Miller, Stephanie Swart and Shafik Quoraishee

item.title: Outgoing Leader of N.Y.C. Antisemitism Office Criticizes His Replacement
item.description: The criticism from the former head of the Office to Combat Antisemitism, Moshe Davis, reflects the social and political divide among Jewish New Yorkers over Mayor Zohran Mamdani.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Sally Goldenberg

media:content.media:credit: Adam Gray for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani appointed Phylisa Wisdom this week to lead the New York City Office to Combat Antisemitism.

item.title: Halle Berry Confirms Her Engagement to Van Hunt
item.description: The actress and producer confirmed her engagement on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon,” unveiling an heirloom-style ring.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora

item.title: Stocks Rebound After Volatile Week as Dow Hits Record High
item.description: The Dow Jones industrial average surpassed 50,000 points for the first time, as old line stocks come back into vogue.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

media:content.media:credit: Brendan Mcdermid/Reuters
media:content.media:description: The Dow Jones industrial average on Friday had its best day since May as it closed above 50,000 points for the first time.

item.title: Contentious Herbicide Is Greenlit in a Blow to the MAHA Agenda
item.description: The chemical, dicamba, is used to control weeds on genetically engineered crops. Courts previously had restricted its use.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi

media:content.media:credit: Tom Polansek/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Dicamba, one of the most widely used herbicides in the United States, is often used on soybeans.

item.title: Maryland Gov. Wes Moore on 2028, Democrats’ Problems and His Favorite Crab Cake
item.description: The Maryland governor discussed Trump, the country’s divisions and his workout routine.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gov. Wes Moore of Maryland

item.title: Body of Nathan Smith, Lil Jon’s Son, Found in Georgia Pond, Police Say
item.description: Nathan Smith, whose stage name is DJ Young Slade, was reported missing on Tuesday after running out of his home in a community north of Atlanta.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler

media:content.media:credit: Kevin Mazur/Getty Images for Pencils of Promise
media:content.media:description: The rapper Lil Jon, left, with his son, Nathan Smith, in 2018. The police said the body of Mr. Smith was recovered from a pond in Georgia on Friday.

item.title: Let the Games Begin
item.description: Also, mass market paperbacks are heading toward extinction. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The opening ceremony at San Siro stadium in Milan.

item.title: Hochul Takes Aim at Trump as She Wins N.Y. Democrats’ Nomination
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul seemed eager to portray herself as a leader ready to stand up to the Trump administration, as she vies for re-election in November.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes and Grace Ashford

media:content.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul collected 85.3 percent of the weighted vote from state committee members at the Democratic State Convention, cementing her role as the party’s front-runner.

item.title: Cuban Deportees Who Were Transferred to Guantánamo Sent Back to U.S.
item.description: Dozens of men appear to be caught up in a political standoff between the Trump administration and Cuba.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg

media:content.media:credit: Lauren Wood/The Natchez Democrat, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: All but one of the men were being held on Friday at the Adams County Correctional Center in Natchez, Miss.

item.title: JD Vance Is Booed at Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony in Milan
item.description: Before the event, protesters marched in Milan in opposition to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, whose personnel are in Italy to advise local officials in securing the Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn

media:content.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Vice President JD Vance and Usha Vance at San Siro stadium for the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics in Milan on Friday.

item.title: In the Grip of Gangs, Haiti Faces a Government Leadership Vacuum
item.description: The tenure of a presidential council that has been running Haiti expires on Saturday. It’s unclear what will come next.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, David C. Adams and André Paultre

media:content.media:credit: Clarens Siffroy/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: A view from inside an armored police vehicle showing cars burned by armed gangs and used as a barricade on a deserted street Port-au-Prince, Haiti, last month.

item.title: Record-Breaking 244-Pound Atlantic Halibut Caught in Quebec
item.description: A huge Atlantic halibut caught in Quebec weighed in at a record-breaking 244 pounds.
item.dc:creator: Jackeline Luna

item.title: Moderates Pitch Tough-on-Crime Message for Democrats Amid Immigration Talks
item.description: A polling memo circulated among centrist senators urged Democrats to talk tougher on crime, an issue where they lag Republicans, while noting an opportunity for the party to appeal to voters with criticism of ICE.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Senator Catherine Cortez Masto, Democrat of Nevada, has been urging her colleagues to strengthen their credibility on the issue of crime and public safety.

item.title: Amazon’s ‘Top Choice Is the Worst Choice’
item.description: What does Amazon’s top choice product designation really mean? The authors Cory Doctorow and Tim Wu describe how the ranking is not based on quality but on the extraction of our attention and money.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: The Internet Feels Miserable ‘By Design’
item.description: Slop, rage bait, brain rot. The authors Cory Doctorow and Tim Wu explain how today’s internet keeps us hooked and makes us angry, and what we can do about it.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: White House Suggests Smithsonian Add a Trump Display
item.description: Administration officials met with staff at the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery and discussed putting multiple artworks of the president in a section of the museum.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Robin Pogrebin

media:content.media:credit: Rod Lamkey/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: The Smithsonian changed President Trump’s portrait in the National Gallery last month to an image by the photographer Daniel Torok.

item.title: Easy, Chocolate Dessert Recipes for Valentine’s Day
item.description: Brownie brittle, chocolate lava cake and more recipes to help celebrate Valentine’s Day, or just any old Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Allison Jiang

media:content.media:credit: Kelly Marshall for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Samantha Seneviratne. Prop Stylist: Paige Hicks.
media:content.media:description: Samantha Seneviratne’s turtle bars.

item.title: Trump Ties Tunnel Funds to Renaming of Transit Hubs
item.description: Administration officials told Senator Chuck Schumer that the president would release federal funds for the Hudson River Gateway project if New York’s Penn Station and Washington Dulles International Airport were renamed after President Trump, according to four people familiar with the private conversations.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling

media:content.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A construction site for the Gateway mass transit project in Manhattan on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Is Hosting Governors at the White House, but Only Republicans
item.description: The president’s decision to exclude Democratic governors from an annual meeting later this month breaks a longstanding tradition.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager

media:content.media:credit: Michael Ciaglo for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gov. Jared Polis of Colorado has clashed with President Trump in recent months over Mr. Polis’s refusal to pardon Tina Peters, a former county clerk.

item.title: Saalumarada Thimmakka Dies; Planted and Nurtured Thousands of Trees
item.description: Believed to be 113, she spent decades building an environmental legacy in India, inspired by her grief at being unable to conceive children.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B.

item.title: How Nintendo Became the Most Fun Video Game Company
item.description: Video games are big business, and the company behind Mario, Zelda and Pokémon may be the most important player, says the author of a new corporate history.
item.category: Super Nintendo: The Game-Changing Company That Unlocked the Power of Play (Book)

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; Inset cover: via Knopf

item.title: France and Canada Open Consulates in Greenland, Following Trump Threats
item.description: Greenland’s mini diplomatic scene is about to get more lively as Canada and France set up consulates, following threats by President Trump to take over the island.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Maya Tekeli

media:content.media:credit: Stoyan Nenov/Reuters
media:content.media:description: The opening of the Canadian Consulate in a building shared with the Icelandic consulate in Nuuk, Greenland, on Friday.

item.title: Flying Solo: Some Olympic Athletes Are Their Country’s Whole Team
item.description: At the Winter Games, athletes from 15 different nations are the only competitor from their countries.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight

media:content.media:credit: Lintao Zhang/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Four years ago, at age 17, Aruwin Salehhuddin became the first female athlete to represent Malaysia at the Olympics. But there was a male athlete, too, and they carried the flag together. This year, she will be carrying it alone.

item.title: NYC Ferry Service Remains Shut Down Amid Bitter Cold and Ice
item.description: Ice has clogged the East River, suspending NYC Ferry service for thousands of commuters. More cold and snow is expected this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen and Samantha Latson

media:content.media:credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Since the snowstorm in New York City last month, large sheets of ice have formed in the Hudson River north of the city and drifted south, making navigation along the ferry service’s routes difficult.

item.title: Athletes Parade at 4 Sites in Italy to Kick Off Winter Olympics
item.description: The exuberant opening ceremonies featured performances by Mariah Carey and Italian stars. Some in the crowd in Milan’s stadium booed Vice President JD Vance.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
